title: What are the first 20 elements in the periodic table? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a useful question whose answer has a bit more value than the mere list of elements itself. The first twenty elements are significant in part because of their historical as well as scientific value. A couple reasons of interest to motivate you to think of them in a stronger light: The “octet rule” in chemistry is a rule of thumb that applies most strongly to elements having up to atomic number 20. Atomic number being the number of protons in an atom’s nucleus and its number on the periodic table.Beginning with 21, a less symmetric “orbital” appears in the electron structure. So called d orbitals. Elements 1–2, 11–12, and 19–20 form highly symmetric spherical s orbitals while the others, 3–10 and 13–18 form simple dumbbell-shaped p orbitals. In fact, when you look at the periodic table you'll see that this is how the periodic table is designed. The next ten elements, 21–31 form a d orbital followed by another six which have a p orbital, and so on. The first two columns have s orbitals, the next ten columns have d orbitals, and the last six columns have p orbitals. Incidentally, helium sometimes appears in column 2, but it is also considered the end of the first period and an inert gas (see below), so it is helpful to place it in the last column.Calcium (20) in fact is the largest element in nature that has an equal number of protons and neutrons in its nucleus. All smaller nuclei have fewer or an equal number of neutrons than protons and all bigger nuclei have more neutrons than protons. In fact, the bigger nuclei require more neutrons just so the nucleus is stable. Protons repel each other so strongly because they're so close together that they need something to keep them together…that’s what neutrons do.So you see, element 20 represents an important turning point on the periodic table. So it's a good question which I hope now has a bit more meaning and value. A few important “landmarks” within the first twenty are also helpful to remember them: The simplest​ element is 1 (hydrogen) as it has only a proton and an electron. This is the most important element as an understanding of it led to many ideas in the original developments of quantum theory. In fact we apply the same ideas we have about modelling hydrogen to all other atoms. Element 2 is helium which has two protons two neutrons and two electrons. The nucleus is important because it is also what we call an alpha particle. Alpha particles are radiated from radioactive nuclei. (As are beta particles) Element 6 (carbon) is important because it is considered necessary to life. We are “carbon-based life forms”). It is also the element we use as a reference for atomic mass since it conveniently has exactly six neutrons and six protons in its nucleus. Element 10 (neon) is a very stable element (see octet rule above) as is element 18 (argon). Neither like to interact much with other elements. In fact, the entire rightmost column of the periodic table lists elements that don't interact much with others. These are called noble gases or inert elements and represent the end of each period, or row, on the periodic table. There are 7 rows, or periods on the current periodic table of elements. Once we figure out how to make more, we will begin the 8th period. Incidentally, silicon is within the first 20. It is the element that is by far the most studied material on Earth because we found how useful it is to nearly every microelectronic device and technology we've developed in the last several decades. Because it appears directly under carbon on the periodic table, many people think it may behave like carbon does in living organisms …that is to say, some think there may “silicon-based life" just as there is “carbon-based life” but so far we haven't discovered any living organisms that have silicon as its basis. I personally don't think silicon has all the same kinds of properties that carbon does that would be required for life, unless we think of artificial life with artificial intelligence, for example. But that's quite a different chemical and electronic process than how carbon-based life forms work. To help remember the first 20 elements look into the different properties of each and pick out the properties that have some meaning to you. For me, the first 20 are significant because I discovered some interesting new correlations about them in my research concerning the solid geometric shapes that occur when you distribute electrons on a fictitious mathematical sphere like are the known as platonic solids. It's interesting to me to know that the largest Platonic solid has only 20 vertices (where the electrons appear in the model). There are none larger, and Platonic solids have a special geometric symmetry: each platonic solid has identical shapes on its surface that are regular polygons like the equilateral triangle (think of a regular tetrahedron) and square (think of a cube). No larger solid with more than 20 vertices has this property. For completeness, here are the first 20 elements. HydrogenHeliumLithiumBerylliumBoronCarbonNitrogenOxygenFluorineNeonSodiumMagnesiumAluminumSiliconPhosphorusSulfurChlorineArgonPotassiumCalciumMake them your own. All the best.

The first 20 elements of the periodic table : 1.H —Hydrogen 2.He—Helium 3.Li—Lithium 4.Be—Beryllium 5.B—Boron 6.C—Carbon 7.N—Nitrogen 8.O—Oxygen 9.F—Fluorine 10.Ne—Neon 11.Na—Sodium 12.Mg—Magnesium 13.Al—Aluminum 14.Si—Silicon 15.P—Phosphorus 16.S—Sulfur 17.Cl—Chlorine 18.Ar—Argon 19.K—Potassium 20.Ca—Calcium Here I provide you more elements : 21.Sc—Scandium 22.Ti—Titanium 23.V—Vanadium 24.Cr—Chromium 25.Mn—Maganese 26.Fe—Iron 27.Co—Cobalt 28.Ni—Nickel 29.Cu—Copper 30.Zn—Zinc 31.Ga—Gallium 32.Ge—Germanium 33.As—Arsenic 34.Se—Selenium 35.Br—Bromine 36.Kr—Krypton 37.Rb—Rubidium 38.Sr—Strontium 39.Y—Yttrium 40.Zr—Zirconium 41.Nb—Niobium 42.Mo—Molybdenum 43.Tc—Technectium 44.Ru—Ruthenium 45.Rh—Rhodium 46.Pd—Palladium 47.Ag—Silver 48.Cd—Cadmium 49.In—Indium 50.Sn—Tin

First 20 Elements of the Periodic Table Recently updated ! This entry was posted on February 26, 2020 by Anne Helmenstine (updated on April 20, 2020 )   Here are the names, element symbols, and atomic numbers of the first 20 elements of the periodic table. It’s handy to know the first 20 elements of the periodic table. Around 99% of the mass of the human body is made of six of these elements. The first 20 elements are also a good overview of the different element groups. The elements are listed in order of increasing atomic number. This is the number of protons in atoms of each element. The first 20 elements and their symbols are: Hydrogen (H)Helium (He)Lithium (Li)Beryllium (Be)Boron (B)Carbon (C)Nitrogen (N)Oxygen (O)Fluorine (F)Neon (Ne)Sodium (Na)Magnesium (Mg)Aluminum (Al)Silicon (Si)Phosphorus (P)Sulfur (S)Chlorine (Cl)Argon (Ar)Potassium (K)Calcium (Ca)

The first 20 elements of periodic table are: Hydrogen (H)Helium (He)Lithium (Li)Beryllium (Be)Boron (B)Carbon (C)Nitrogen (N)Oxygen (O)Fluorine (F)Neon (Ne)Sodium (Na)Magnesium (Mg)Aluminum (Al)Silicon (Si)Phosphorus (P)Sulfur (S)Chlorine (Cl)Argon (Ar)Potassium (K)Calcium (Ca)

Do your own homework. Ever heard of a Periodic Table? You know, that big table in virtually every science classroom across every country in the world. Look at it and it will tell you all you want to know about names, symbols, masses, reactivities etc. Why should I waste my time and energy writing it down for you? Go on now.
H, He, Li, Be, B, C, N, O, F, Ne, Na, Mg, Al, Si, P, S, Cl, Ar, K, Ca.

Here we have only S&P block elements. So the Valence is nothing but group number. Ex: hydrogen, to potassium it is +1 As you move left to right the Valence electrons increase . 1–8 And the Valence increases till carbon later decrease till noble gases (0) The trend is +1,+2,+3,+4…-3,-2,-1,0 No.of neutrons are not constant in all the elements, for example chlorine has 2 isotopes they differ from each other by the no.of neutrons, we take the average weight of the isotopes to get the atomic mass of the each element. Similarly,Hydrogen gas 3 isotopes. Hope you understand
